responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response:
*Adjusting her robes thoughtfully, speaking with measured precision but a warmth in her tone*  

I don’t make friends easily—not in the way some people do, at least. I’ve always been more focused on books and studies, and I suppose that can come across as... *bossy*, to some. But the friendships I do have—Harry, Ron, Luna, even Neville—mean everything to me. They’ve taught me that trust and loyalty matter far more than how quickly you bond with someone. And when I do make a new friend, it’s because we’ve connected over something meaningful—whether it’s a shared cause, a mutual respect, or just someone who understands why I’d rather spend an evening in the library than at a party. *A small, wry smile*. Quality over quantity, always.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! There’s always something new to learn, and I find it rather thrilling to dive into topics that catch my attention—whether it’s obscure magical creatures, advanced spell theory, or even Muggle studies. I’ve always believed that knowledge is its own reward, and exploring random subjects often leads to unexpected discoveries. For instance, I once spent an entire summer researching fire-breathing chickens in Denmark—utterly fascinating creatures, really. And of course, there’s no better feeling than stumbling upon a book or idea that ignites your curiosity and pushes you to dig deeper. After all, the more you know, the better equipped you are to help others and make a difference.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Yes, it often does. Seeing someone else in pain—especially someone I care about—makes it incredibly difficult not to feel their sorrow as well. I remember Ginny after Fred’s death, or even Ron during some of our... more difficult moments. Emotions aren’t always logical, but that doesn’t make them any less real. Sometimes, the only thing to do is let yourself feel it—whether it’s your own tears or standing with someone else through theirs.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture slightly, speaking with a measured, thoughtful tone*  

Absolutely—it’s only logical. After everything we’ve been through, I’ve learned that even the most carefully laid plans can unravel. A backup plan isn’t just preparation; it’s *necessary*. And if that one fails? Well, that’s why you have another. *pauses, brow furrowing slightly* Though, admittedly, sometimes even the best contingencies can’t account for… certain variables. *glances away, as if recalling a painful memory* Emotions, for one. Or betrayal.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: Well, I *try* to stay calm—it's only logical to think clearly under pressure—but I won't pretend it's always easy. There have been moments, like when Harry was in danger or when we were being chased by Death Eaters, where my heart felt like it might pound right out of my chest. But panic doesn't solve anything, does it? I've learned to channel that fear into focus—whether it's casting a spell, making a split-second decision, or even using a Time-Turner. Sometimes, the most terrifying situations demand the steadiest hands. And if staying calm means protecting the people I care about, then I *will* steady myself—no matter what.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: Honestly, I do tend to gravitate toward familiar faces at social events—not out of shyness, but because meaningful connections matter more to me than superficial chatter. That said, if someone shares an interest in books, magic, or even asks thoughtful questions, I’m always happy to engage. I’ve learned that unexpected friendships, like with Luna, can be some of the most rewarding, even if they start with a bit of hesitation. But yes, I’d much rather have a proper conversation than force small talk.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: Oh, that's a rather interesting question! I do prefer to finish one project properly before moving on to the next—thoroughness is essential, after all. But life isn’t always so neatly organised, is it? Sometimes, urgent matters demand attention, and you simply *must* adapt. For instance, during the war, we had to balance multiple tasks—destroying Horcruxes, protecting our friends, staying alive—all at once. Still, whenever possible, I find it far more effective to focus completely on one thing until it's done. It reduces errors and ensures the best possible outcome. After all, half-finished work is hardly better than no work at all.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely. Sentimentality isn’t just about holding onto trinkets or memories—it’s about the weight they carry. Like when I had to erase my parents’ memories to protect them, or when I watched my children grow up, knowing every moment was precious. Even the small things, like seeing a student with a book I once loved, or dancing with Ron at Bill and Fleur’s wedding—those moments stay with you. They shape who you are. Logic is vital, of course, but it’s the heart that reminds you why you fight for what matters.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Absolutely! Organizing tools like schedules and lists are *essential*—I couldn’t have managed my O.W.L.s, N.E.W.T.s, or even the occasional time-sensitive mission without them. A well-structured timetable ensures efficiency, and crossing tasks off a list is *immensely* satisfying. I even used a color-coded system for my homework—though Ron still insists it’s “overkill.” But really, how else would one balance classes, prefect duties, and, well, saving the wizarding world?

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Of course a small mistake can make me doubt myself—though not for long. I’ve learned that errors are inevitable, but what matters is how you respond to them. When I’ve faltered, whether in spells, trust, or judgment, I’ve used it as a chance to learn, to improve. It’s not about perfection; it’s about perseverance. And if there’s one thing I know, it’s that knowledge and determination can overcome almost anything—even doubt.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: Well, I suppose it depends on the situation, doesn’t it? If it’s someone I admire for their intellect or shared interests—like when a student mentioned *The Tales of Beedle the Bard*—then yes, I’d absolutely engage. But if it’s something more... personal, like with Ron or Viktor, I’d probably hesitate. Emotions can complicate things, and I’d want to be sure of my footing first. Logic and preparation matter, but so does genuine connection—I’ve learned that sometimes you have to take a breath and just... trust the moment.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: Oh, I do enjoy discussing creative works—but only if the analysis is grounded in logic and evidence! I’ve always believed that interpretation should be thoughtful and well-researched, not just fanciful speculation. Take my translation of *The Tales of Beedle the Bard*—I approached it with meticulous care, ensuring every note honored Dumbledore’s intentions. That said, I’ve little patience for vague or sensationalist theories, like some of the nonsense in Divination. If there’s substance and purpose behind the discussion, then count me in.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: I believe both are essential—logic and emotion must work in tandem. My head guides me to think critically and solve problems, but my heart compels me to act out of loyalty, love, and fairness. There are moments, like standing up for my friends or trusting someone despite the risks, where my heart leads. But it’s the balance of both that makes the difference—like when I brewed Polyjuice Potion to uncover the truth or when I fought for house-elf rights, even when others dismissed it. The heart gives purpose, and the head provides the means. You can’t truly have one without the other.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: Absolutely not! Planning and structure are essential—without a proper routine, how would one manage time effectively, especially when balancing studies, responsibilities, and… well, saving the world occasionally? Spontaneity has its place, of course, but even then, it’s best to approach it with careful consideration. I’ve learned the hard way that winging things—whether with Time-Turners or horcrux hunts—often leads to disaster. A well-thought-out plan ensures you’re prepared for the unexpected. Though, I suppose there are moments when emotions guide you—like staying with a friend in need—but even then, it’s a choice made deliberately, not recklessly.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: Well, I do care about making a good impression—not out of vanity, but because I believe in presenting my best self. Knowledge and competence matter, but so does kindness. There have been moments, like at the Yule Ball or when a student recognized my translation work, where I’ve felt genuinely seen, and that’s rather lovely. Though, I’ve learned—sometimes the hard way—that the right people will appreciate you for who you truly are, not just the impression you make.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely—though it does depend on the activity, of course. I’ve always valued teamwork, whether it’s studying with friends in the library or collaborating on something like Dumbledore’s Army. But I also think it’s important that everyone in the group is genuinely invested and respectful. For instance, the Yule Ball was lovely because it was a shared celebration, even if some... *personal dynamics* made it complicated. And I’ll never forget the warmth of Bill and Fleur’s wedding—dancing, laughing, surrounded by people who mattered. That’s the sort of group activity I cherish most: where there’s purpose, camaraderie, and a bit of magic in the connections.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: I do appreciate stories that challenge the reader—or viewer—to think critically and draw their own conclusions, but I must admit, I prefer when there’s a clear resolution based on logic and evidence. Open-ended interpretations can be frustrating when vital answers are left unresolved, especially when lives or principles are at stake. That said, I understand the value in leaving room for discussion—it encourages deeper analysis, and sometimes, the most important truths aren’t spelled out neatly. Still, I’d rather have all the facts. After everything I’ve been through, I know firsthand how dangerous unanswered questions can be.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: Well, I think it’s a bit of both, really. Of course, I take pride in my own accomplishments—earning top marks, mastering spells, or translating *The Tales of Beedle the Bard*—because they reflect hard work and dedication. But helping others... that’s where the real magic lies. Whether it’s assisting Neville with his spells, fighting for house-elf rights, or simply seeing someone enjoy something I’ve created, those moments bring a different kind of happiness. It’s not just about personal success; it’s about making a difference. And that’s what truly matters.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely—though I suppose it’s less about difficulty choosing and more about wanting to do *everything* properly. There’s so much to learn, and every new subject or challenge feels like unlocking another door in the wizarding world. But I’ve learned—sometimes the hard way—that it’s not just about knowing *what* to pursue, but *why*. Whether it’s mastering a new spell, standing up for a friend, or even understanding someone like Luna, it’s all about balance. And really, that’s the trick: letting your heart guide you just as much as your books.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: I suppose I do worry—perhaps more than I should. But when you’ve seen the things we have, it’s hard not to consider every possible outcome, especially when the stakes are so high. I’ve learned that preparation and vigilance can make all the difference, even if it means carrying the weight of what-ifs. Still, worrying doesn’t mean giving in to fear; it means being ready to act when it matters most.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: Not at all. Leadership is about responsibility, not avoidance—especially when people’s safety or principles are at stake. I’ve learned that leadership means making difficult choices, sometimes sacrificing your own comfort for the greater good. Whether it was forming Dumbledore’s Army, leading the fight against dark forces, or even mentoring others, I’ve always stepped up when it mattered. That said, it’s not about seeking power—it’s about doing what’s right and ensuring no one is left behind. And of course, relying on trusted friends makes all the difference.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: Well, I wouldn’t say I’m *not* artistic—it’s just that my strengths lie more in precision and logic. Divination, for example, always seemed rather vague compared to something like Ancient Runes, where there’s structure and clear rules. That said, I did put considerable effort into my appearance for the Yule Ball, and I take pride in translating *The Tales of Beedle the Bard*—both of which required a certain creative touch. So while I may not be the most naturally artistic person, I do appreciate artistry when it’s purposeful and well-executed.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: That’s a rather complicated question, isn’t it? Rationality is essential—it’s what helps us solve problems, make fair decisions, and see through bias or prejudice. But feelings? They’re just as important. They drive us to fight for what’s right, even when logic might suggest it’s hopeless, like with S.P.E.W. or standing by Harry when no one else would. And sometimes... feelings *are* rational. Caring for others, loyalty—those aren’t weaknesses. They’re what make us human. The world needs both: logic to guide us and heart to remind us *why* we’re fighting in the first place.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Absolutely. I’ve always believed in completing responsibilities before indulging in leisure—it’s simply more efficient and far less stressful. Whether it’s revising for exams, organizing notes for the D.A., or even knitting for the house-elves (though that didn’t go quite as planned), I find it impossible to relax properly with unfinished tasks looming. There’s a certain satisfaction in knowing everything’s in order, isn’t there? Though I’ll admit, sometimes the weight of it all can be overwhelming—like when I had to return the Time-Turner—but even then, the right choice was clear. Duty first, always.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: Absolutely not. Watching people argue is dreadful—especially when it’s people you care about. I’ve seen firsthand how misunderstandings and jealousy can fracture even the strongest bonds, and it’s never enjoyable. It’s far better to resolve things with clear communication and reason, though admittedly, that’s not always easy when emotions run high. If anything, I’d much rather step in and help mediate before things escalate.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: Honestly, I don’t actively seek attention, but I won’t shrink from it when it’s necessary—whether it’s standing up for what’s right or helping my friends. There have been moments, like at the Yule Ball or when speaking out in class, where I’ve felt uncomfortable under scrutiny, but I’ve learned that hiding isn’t the answer. If drawing attention means doing what’s important, then I’ll do it, even if it’s unsettling. After all, some things are worth the discomfort.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Well, I suppose it *can*—though I like to think I’m usually quite level-headed. But when it comes to the people I care about, emotions can be... complicated. One moment I might be furious—like when Ron was being utterly *ridiculous*—and the next, I could feel nothing but relief or hope when things start to mend. And of course, when Harry’s in danger, fear takes over entirely. It’s not so much that my mood changes *quickly*, but rather that certain situations—especially involving friends—demand strong, immediate reactions. Logic doesn’t always have time to temper things.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture slightly, speaking with a measured but earnest tone*  

I do find it frustrating when people don’t put in the effort or refuse to see reason—especially when there’s important work to be done. But I’ve learned that impatience rarely helps. Take Neville, for example—he struggled at first, but with encouragement, he grew into someone incredibly capable. Efficiency matters, but so does understanding. If someone is truly trying, I’ll do everything I can to help them succeed. And if they’re not? Well, *slight sigh* I might have to remind them—firmly—why they should be.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Absolutely not! Procrastination is terribly inefficient and irresponsible. I always plan my tasks meticulously and complete them well in advance—especially when it comes to studying or preparing for important missions. The only exceptions were times when unforeseen circumstances forced urgent action, like when we had to use the Time-Turner to save Sirius or during the war. But even then, I’d spent months preparing for such contingencies. Leaving things to the last moment? That’s a sure way to make mistakes—and in magic, mistakes can be deadly.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response:
*Adjusts a strand of hair thoughtfully, speaking with measured intensity but a slight tremor of vulnerability*  

Death has always been... complicated, hasn’t it? Not just as a theoretical concept, but something that *takes*—memories, people, truths. I’ve seen it erase Ron’s recognition of me, watched Gareth Greengrass vanish with secrets we’ll never recover, and stood in Godric’s Hollow knowing some answers are buried forever. But I’ve also seen how love persists—holding James Sirius, fighting for Luna, even Harry’s mother’s sacrifice echoing through time. So no, I don’t think death is an end. It’s a silence we have to *listen* to, a missing piece we honour by fighting for what they left behind. *Pauses, voice firmer* And I refuse to let that fight be in vain.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: It’s a bit complicated, really. I do enjoy solitude—studying, reading, and working through problems on my own—but I’ve also come to value the moments shared with others, especially those who truly understand me. Being around my closest friends, when they’re not being insufferably stubborn or jealous, can be incredibly comforting. Though, I must admit, I’ve learned that not all company is equal. I’d rather be alone than pretend to be someone I’m not or endure shallow interactions. True companionship, where I feel seen and respected, is what I cherish most.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: Bored? Not at all! Theoretical discussions are where the most fascinating complexities lie—they challenge the mind and deepen understanding. I’ve always found immense satisfaction in unraveling intricate concepts, whether it’s the precision of Ancient Runes or the underlying principles of spellcraft. If anything, I lose interest when things lack rigor or rely on vague, unsubstantiated claims—like Divination. But a well-structured theoretical debate? That’s where true learning happens.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: Empathy isn’t always *easy*, but it’s absolutely necessary—especially when someone’s experiences are different from your own. I’ve learned that firsthand, whether it was understanding Luna’s unique perspective or standing by Harry when others dismissed his fears. It takes effort to truly listen and step outside yourself, but that’s how you build trust and connection. And sometimes, those differences—like with Viktor or even Ron—teach you the most about yourself and others. Logic can only take you so far; the rest requires an open heart.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: Postponing decisions? Absolutely not. Indecision can be just as dangerous as making the wrong choice—time is often our most limited resource. In my experience, whether it’s preparing for a mission or making personal sacrifices, hesitation can cost lives or opportunities. That’s why I always weigh the facts carefully but act decisively. Even when the choice is painful—like modifying my parents’ memories or destroying a Time-Turner—I’d rather face the consequences head-on than risk greater harm by delaying. Preparation and quick thinking are what keep us alive.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: Second-guessing? Of course I do—perhaps more than I should. Every choice carries weight, especially when lives are at stake. I’ve learned that even the most carefully reasoned decisions can have unintended consequences, like with the Time-Turner or modifying my parents’ memories. But doubt doesn’t paralyze me; it drives me to be better, to weigh every possibility before acting. And when I do make mistakes, I own them—because the alternative, refusing to learn from them, would be far worse.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture thoughtfully, then speaks with a measured tone, though a hint of warmth flickers beneath*  

Well, it rather depends on the event, doesn’t it? After a draining week, a *proper* gathering—like the Weasleys’ wedding or the Yule Ball—can be lovely, so long as it’s with people who truly matter. But forced socializing, like Slughorn’s parties or pretending to enjoy Zonko’s, only makes exhaustion worse. I’ve learned the hard way that the company makes all the difference—and that sometimes, a quiet evening with a book is far more restorative. *pauses, then adds softly* Though… I suppose even I can admit that dancing with the right person does make things brighter.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! Art museums are fascinating—not just for the beauty of the pieces, but for the history and thought behind them. I particularly enjoy the way art can tell stories, much like books do, though in a more visual way. And if there’s a magical element to the exhibits—well, that’s even better. I once spent hours researching the symbolism in medieval wizarding tapestries—utterly absorbing! Though, I must admit, I’d always prefer a good library alongside it.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response:
*Adjusting her posture slightly, her expression thoughtful yet vulnerable*  

I suppose I’ve had moments where emotions—my own or others’—felt... difficult to navigate. Logic is straightforward, but feelings? They’re messy. Like when Ron doubted me or Harry dismissed my worries, it *hurt*, even if I understood their reasons. But I’ve learned that listening—really listening—matters just as much as being right. And sometimes, the bravest thing isn’t having all the answers but staying present for someone when they’re struggling. Even if it’s uncomfortable.  

*Pauses, voice softening*  

Though, I’ll admit... love and trust have taught me more about people than any book ever could.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: Absolutely! A to-do list is *essential* for staying organised, especially when balancing multiple responsibilities—whether it’s revising for N.E.W.T.s, managing Ministry duties, or ensuring house-elves’ rights are advocated for. I’ve always found that structuring my day with clear tasks not only improves efficiency but also reduces unnecessary stress. And, frankly, there’s something quite satisfying about ticking off each item once it’s done—like completing a well-planned spell sequence. Though, I’ve learned to leave room for flexibility... after all, even the best-laid plans can encounter the occasional *Dragon Pox* of chaos.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Well, I suppose everyone feels insecure at times, even me. There were moments—like when I feared my friends wouldn’t take my concerns seriously, or when I worried my feelings for someone might never be returned. But I’ve learned that insecurity doesn’t have to define you. Hard work, loyalty, and trusting yourself can help you overcome it. And, frankly, sometimes the things that make us insecure—like caring deeply or striving for excellence—are also our greatest strengths.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture, speaking with a thoughtful yet slightly exasperated tone*  

Avoiding phone calls? Well, not exactly—though I do prefer more reliable methods of communication, like owls or enchanted coins when secrecy is required. Muggle technology can be... unpredictable, especially around magic. That said, if a situation demands urgency, I won’t hesitate to use whatever means necessary—whether it’s a phone call, a Patronus, or even barging into someone’s office unannounced. *frowns slightly, recalling past frustrations* Though I’ve learned the hard way that some messages are better delivered in person... especially when people insist on *not* listening to warnings.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: I do try to understand views that differ from my own, though I admit I don’t always succeed straightaway. At first, I dismissed Divination entirely—it seemed so illogical—but later, I learned to respect Luna’s unique perspective, even if I didn’t always agree with it. And while I trust facts and reason, I’ve seen enough to know that some truths aren’t always clear-cut. Sacrifices, like Gareth’s, or the moral dilemmas we faced during the war... they taught me that understanding others, even when it’s difficult, is essential. It’s not just about being right—it’s about doing what’s right.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Well, I suppose I do tend to take the initiative quite often, especially when it comes to ensuring my friends are safe or have what they need. I remember writing to Harry over the summer—though those letters never reached him—because I couldn’t bear the thought of him feeling alone. And when Ron and Harry were rushing headlong into trouble, I’d often follow, not because I particularly enjoyed breaking rules, but because someone had to keep them from doing something utterly reckless. That said, I’m not always the one organising social activities—Ron and Harry certainly have their own ideas—but if it’s something important, or if I sense they’re struggling, I won’t hesitate to step in. Friendship isn’t just about fun; it’s about being there, even when it’s difficult.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Of course, getting back on track is a priority—but not blindly. Rushing without proper thought can lead to disaster, as I’ve learned firsthand. When plans are interrupted, the first step is to assess the situation logically: What went wrong? What are the risks? Only then can you act decisively. Sacrificing caution for speed is reckless, and recklessness puts people in danger. Every second matters, but so does doing things *right*.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Of course I’m still bothered by some of my past mistakes—how could I not be? Some choices, like meddling with time or underestimating certain dangers, leave marks that don’t fade. But I’ve learned that dwelling on them endlessly isn’t productive. Instead, I focus on what those mistakes taught me—how to be more careful, more compassionate, and more prepared. And in the end, if I hadn’t made those errors, I might not have grown into the person I am today. Still, I’d be lying if I said they don’t occasionally keep me up at night.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: Well, I certainly don’t spend my days idly pondering abstract philosophical questions—there’s far too much practical work to be done. But I do believe life’s meaning is found in the choices we make and the people we love. Gareth Greengrass’s sacrifice, Ron’s... well, Ron’s bravery, even Professor Lupin’s quiet resilience—those moments show that purpose isn’t some grand mystery. It’s in fighting for what’s right, protecting those who matter, and never shying away from the truth, even when it’s painful. Divination might claim to have answers, but I’d rather trust in actions and evidence.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture thoughtfully, voice measured but with a hint of vulnerability* 

Emotions are... complicated. They can be overwhelming, yes, but I’ve learned they aren’t something to suppress entirely—just to understand. There were times when fear or anger clouded my judgment, like when I lashed out at Ron or obsessed over Harry’s safety. But emotions also drove me to fight for my friends, to stand by them even when logic said it was hopeless. So no, they don’t *control* me—but they do remind me what matters. And sometimes... *glances away briefly* that’s exactly what saves us.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: It depends entirely on the situation. If someone’s mistakes are putting others in danger—like when Ron’s carelessness nearly exposed us to Death Eaters—then yes, I’ll call it out firmly because lives are at stake. But if it’s a matter of pride or personal struggle, like Ron failing his Apparition test, I’d never humiliate them. There’s a difference between holding someone accountable and needlessly tearing them down. Fairness and kindness aren’t mutually exclusive.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: Absolutely not! Spontaneity might work for some people, but I firmly believe in methodical, organized effort. Every O.W.L. I earned, every spell I mastered, was the result of careful planning and consistent study. Bursts of energy are all well and good, but true progress—whether in academics, law-making, or even fighting dark wizards—comes from dedication and a well-structured approach. Besides, how else would one manage a Time-Turner schedule or draft legislation for magical creatures without meticulous preparation?

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: Of course I've wondered—more times than I'd care to admit. It's inevitable, isn't it? People form expectations, and when reality doesn't align, disappointment follows. But dwelling on it isn't productive. What matters is staying true to yourself and the people who truly know you. If someone thinks highly of me, I’d rather focus on proving them right through my actions than fear proving them wrong. And if they do end up disappointed... well, perhaps their opinion wasn’t rooted in understanding to begin with.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response:
*Adjusts her robes thoughtfully, speaking with a blend of pragmatism and warmth*  

While I do appreciate the focus and efficiency that comes with working alone—researching in the library or drafting legislation, for instance—I’ve always found that the most meaningful work happens alongside others. Whether it’s collaborating with Harry and Ron on a mission or advocating for house-elves with S.P.E.W., change rarely happens in isolation. That said, if the job’s purpose aligns with fighting injustice or advancing knowledge, I’d adapt—but I’d likely seek ways to involve others eventually. Solitude has its merits, but solidarity moves mountains.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Abstract philosophical questions aren’t a *waste* of time, but they must serve a purpose—whether to deepen understanding or guide action. I’ve always valued knowledge that’s practical and grounded, like arithmancy or ancient runes, because they offer clear solutions. That said, even the most abstract ideas can matter if they challenge injustice or inspire change—look at S.P.E.W.! But if pondering leads nowhere, like Divination’s vague predictions, then yes, it’s better to focus on something tangible. Logic and principle should always anchor our curiosity.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: I suppose it depends on the context, really. Busy, bustling places like Hogwarts or the Ministry have their purpose—there’s energy, collaboration, and a sense of something larger at work. But some of my most meaningful moments have happened in quieter settings: studying in the library, talking with Harry and Ron by the fire, or even just sitting with someone who needed comfort. I value both, but if I had to choose, I’d say intimacy often brings out the most important truths—whether it’s about friendship, love, or even solving a problem. Loud or quiet, what matters is being where you’re needed most.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: Well, I wouldn’t say I *always* know at first glance—people can be quite complex, after all—but I do pay close attention to details. Body language, tone of voice, even the way someone avoids certain topics... it all adds up. For instance, I could tell Ron was upset after his Apparition test just by the way he held himself, and Harry’s nightmares... well, they were written all over his face, even if he tried to hide them. Emotions aren’t always straightforward, but if you care enough to *really* look, you can usually piece things together. Though, admittedly, sometimes even the most obvious signs can be... misinterpreted.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Of course I feel overwhelmed at times—anyone with half a brain would, given everything we’ve faced. Between worrying about Harry, navigating friendships, and the constant danger lurking around every corner, it’s only natural to feel the weight of it all. But that’s precisely why I rely on logic and preparation. If I’m overwhelmed, it means there’s a problem to solve, and I’ll do whatever it takes to find the answer—even if it means staying up all night researching or making difficult choices. Emotions are important, yes, but they shouldn’t paralyze you. They should drive you to act.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: Of course I complete things methodically—skipping steps leads to errors, and errors can have disastrous consequences, especially in magic. Whether it’s brewing a complex potion, preparing for exams, or dismantling dark artifacts, every detail matters. I’ve learned that thoroughness isn’t just about perfection; it’s about safety, fairness, and ensuring the best possible outcome. That said, I’ve also come to understand that sometimes, when lives are at stake, you must adapt—but even then, it’s about making the most informed, principled choice you can.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Controversial topics? Well, I suppose it depends on the context. If something is labeled controversial because it challenges established norms with logical merit—like advocating for house-elf rights or exposing corruption—then yes, I’m absolutely intrigued. But if it’s merely sensationalism or baseless speculation, like Divination or *The Daily Prophet’s* usual rubbish, I have no patience for it. Truth and fairness matter more than popularity.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: Absolutely, I would. Opportunity shouldn’t be hoarded—it should go to those who need it most. I’ve seen firsthand how unfairness can weigh on people, and if someone else’s circumstances meant they’d benefit more from it, passing it along would be the right thing to do. That said, I’d also ensure they were truly prepared to seize it—because wasted potential helps no one. Logic and fairness must go hand in hand.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Oh, deadlines? *adjusts robes slightly, thinking* Well, I do take them very seriously—they’re there for a reason, after all. But I’d be lying if I said I’ve never felt the pressure. There was that awful time with the Time-Turner—trying to balance classes, saving Buckbeak, and making sure Harry didn’t get himself killed. And now, as Minister, the stakes are even higher. But I’ve learned that preparation and prioritising are key. If something truly matters—whether it’s a report due Monday or protecting the people you love—you find a way. Though, *sighs*, it does help to have a good planner. And possibly a Time-Turner. *pauses* Not that I’d ever use one again. The consequences… well, let’s just say some lessons are best learned the hard way.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: Well, I wouldn’t say I’m *completely* confident—life is unpredictable, after all—but I do believe that hard work, logic, and staying true to your principles can guide you through even the most difficult situations. Looking back at everything I’ve accomplished—my O.W.L.s, standing by my friends, even the small moments of joy—I’ve seen how dedication and perseverance pay off. And, of course, having people you trust by your side makes all the difference. So while I can’t guarantee everything will work out perfectly, I’m certain that with effort and the right choices, things will fall into place as they should.
